brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a rule that checks for unresolved file references in the scripts attributes of the @Sql annotation and the corresponding aliased attributes of the @Sql meta annotations in Spring Testing.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'invalid-sql-and-sqlgroup-configurations' checks each class in the project. If a class has either the @Sql or @SqlGroup annotation, it retrieves the 'scripts' attribute of the annotation, which should contain file paths. It then checks each file path to ensure that it exists. If a file path does not exist, it asserts an error and outputs a message indicating the unresolved file reference and the fully qualified name of the class where the issue was found.
PRE_model_validation: The generated rule is syntactically correct and follows the RSL syntax. It uses only the built-in functions provided, and it does not introduce any new functions. The rule is designed to check for unresolved file references in the scripts attributes of the @Sql and @SqlGroup annotations, which aligns with the requirement.

Summary: This page from Baeldung explains how to use the @Sql annotation in Spring Boot to execute SQL scripts, which is relevant to the rule as it checks for unresolved file references in the scripts attributes of the @Sql annotation.

2. URL: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38680527/resolving-sql-script-in-spring-boot
Summary: This StackOverflow thread discusses issues related to resolving SQL scripts in Spring Boot, which is relevant to the rule as it checks for unresolved file references in SQL scripts.
